newsitem.title: USA: TENNIS-HINGIS ERASES SIDOT AT ACURA CLASSIC.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-HINGIS ERASES SIDOT AT ACURA CLASSIC.

text.p: Sixteen-year-old world number one Martina Hingis erased 18-year-old Anne-Gaelle Sidot of France 6-2 6-2 in the second round of the $450,000 Acura Classic Wednesday.
"I won another match," the Swiss teen said. "I feel pretty good."
While Hingis cruised into the quarter-finals, second seed Monica Seles survived and Amy Frazier thrived in their second-round matches on the sweltering centre court.

Seles outlasted stubborn Sandrine Testud of France 6-7 (6-8) 7-6 (7-4) 6-3 in a two-hour, 23-minute tussle and Frazier, the 1994 titleholder, stunned third-seeded and fifth-ranked Amanda Coetzer of South Africa 6-1 6-3 in just 69 minutes.

Defending champion Lindsay Davenport and Natasha Zvereva gained the quarter-finals as well. The fourth-seeded American crushed Yayuk Basuki of Indonesia 6-1 6-1 while Zvereva, of Belarus, edged Rumanian Ruxandra Dragomir 6-2 4-6 7-6 (7-4).
Hingis is seeking her 10th title of the year and third in as many weeks in California.
"Success is my biggest motivation you can get," she said. "I don't like to lose, no one likes losing."

The reigning queen of Wimbledon and the Australian Open displayed her smooth-stroking all-court game to wear down Sidot despite being out-hit 18 winners to 11 during the 59-minute match. However, Hingis's 10 unforced errors were half as many as the error-prone lefthander.
Seles was relieved to gain a measure of revenge against Testud, who knocked her off in the round of 32 at Wimbledon last month.

"It was such an up-and-down match," said the former world number one, who has slipped two spots. "It was the just the same match as when I played her at Wimbledon. It's just that today I was the lucky one."
Seles wasn't so lucky early on. She squandered a pair of set points and survived four more in the tiebreaker before committing two of her 29 unforced errors to give the set away.

"I got down on myself very hard at the beginning of the second set," she said. "I was making too many unforced errors and playing her game. I said, I'm not going to let this happen -- win or lose, keep attacking."
That might not have mattered, though, if Testud had not gotten blinded by the sun.

"At 5-3 (in the second set), I couldn't serve. I couldn't see the ball," Testud said. "That was the only moment in the match that my toss was right in the sun. I couldn't serve as hard and it made a big difference."

Seles immediately capitalised with a break and won the tiebreaker to force a deciding set. Seles got the only break of that set to go ahead 5-3, and claimed the victory moments later when Testud banged a forehand long on match point.
Coetzer had beaten Frazier in both career meetings, including a straight-sets win at this year's French Open. But the American's groundstrokes were as hot as the sizzling court temperatures.

"She has the type of game where she goes for a lot," Coetzer said. "She made quite a lot of shots and I felt like I didn't put a lot of pressure on her. It's a lot easier to make those shots when you don't have a lot of pressure on you."
